Search network by taxa using keyword, tsn, eol, bold or ncbi IDs.

Source: R/search_taxa.R
search_taxa.Rd

Search network by taxa using keyword, tsn, eol, bold or ncbi IDs.

search_taxa(query = NULL, tsn = NULL, gbif = NULL, eol = NULL,
  col = NULL, bold = NULL, ncbi = NULL, original = FALSE,
  verbose = TRUE, ...)

Arguments

query

character query on taxa names
tsn

a numeric. Unique taxonomic identifier from Integrated Taxonomic Information Sytem (https://www.itis.gov/)
gbif

a numeric. Unique taxonomic identifier from Global Biodiversity Information Facility (https://www.gbif.org/)
eol

a numeric. Unique taxonomic identifier from Encyclopedia of Life (https://eol.org/)
col

a numeric. Unique taxonomic identifier from Catalogue of Life (https://www.catalogueoflife.org/)
bold

a numeric. Unique taxonomic identifier from Barcode of Life (http://www.boldsystems.org/)
ncbi

a numeric. Unique taxonomic identifier from National Center for Biotechnology Information (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/)
original

a logical. Should query taxa names from the original publication? (see details section, default is set to FALSE, only work for full text search)
verbose

a logical. Should extra information be reported on progress?
...

further arguments to be passed to rmangal::get_gen().

Value

An object of class mgSearchTaxa, which is a data.frame object with all taxa matching the query. All networks in which taxa are involved are also attached to the data.frame.

Details

By default, you are querying taxa based on a homogenized taxonomy (corrected names from TNRS and/or GNR. These taxa might not be the taxon name used in the original publication. In order to query, the original name, set argument original to TRUE.

Examples

search_taxa("Acer")
#> Full text search
#> Found 5 taxa involved in 5 network(s)
#>     id     original_name node_level network_id taxonomy_id
#> 1 2629      Acer negundo      taxon         19           2
#> 2 2630  Acer saccharinum      taxon         19           3

# Retrieve higher classification
tsn_acer <- search_taxa("Acer")$taxonomy.tsn
#> Full text search
#> Found 5 taxa involved in 5 network(s)
taxize::classification(tsn_acer, db = "itis")
